article.Heading: Planning to book Jeep Compass? Get ready to pay more as GST council approves hike in cess on luxury cars
article.Summary: The cess has been brought in to compensate states for any loss of revenue
article.Body:
Moneycontrol News

If you had decided to book a Jeep Compass finally or any other luxury segment car for that matter, it is time you revise your budget or act fast to get it booked.

A month after Goods and Services Tax kicked in, the GST Council has decided to increase the cess levied on luxury automobiles. The cess will be increased by 10 percent, that is, from 15 percent to 25 percent. However, the rate escalation won’t be effective immediately as the decision will require an amendment to the GST Act.

A table displaying the expected increase in prices of cars after the cess becomes effective

“The council approved an amendment to the GST law to enable an increase in the rate of levy of compensation cess,” a report in The Economic Times quoted a government official aware of the matter.

Cars that are above four metres in length and have an engine capacity of 1500cc comprise the Indian luxury automobile segment. This means SUVs and sedans are set to get costlier once the amendment to the act is done.

Small cars — less than four metres in size and below 1200cc capacity—attract one percent cess for petrol variants. Diesel cars with up to 1500cc capacity and less than four metres in length, the cess is three percent.

All cars are placed in the highest tax bracket of 28 percent under GST. After the new tax regime kicked in, SUVs and other luxury cars got cheaper as 17 state and central taxes and 23 cesses were unified.

Many car manufacturers cut the price to pass on the benefit of the GST. However, some carmakers, particularly of small cars, had to raise the prices after the cess was imposed on them.

The cess has been brought in to compensate states for any loss of revenue due to the imposition of GST. The act has a provision for compensating the states for a period of five years vide the GST (Compensation to the States for Loss of Revenue) Bill, 2016.
